projects.title: Adapt Translations
projects.subtitle: a course project for CS32 Software Engineering - Spring 2017
projects.description: A web app that enables translators to align their original and translated documents for a seamless translation experience.

children.text: Our four-person team started the creation process by reaching out to faculty and students in the Comparative Literature department. By surveying them about their current translation-related behaviors, we learned that most just open two separate windows for their two documents, as well as other windows for online translation resources, but wish they had a better workflow.
portfolio/adapt/adapt-translations-2.gif
We decided to create a visual application that would display how two documents aligned without the user having to manually remember or find these links between documents.
As the only person on the team with front-end experience, I became the lead front-end developer on the project. Here are some of the most interesting features of the front-end that I implemented:
Optional matched scrolling through the two documents; scroll on one side and scroll proportionately through the other
The ability to load documents from files, save and reload old projects
Integration with the popular TinyMCE text editor for a familiar interface
Integration with Google Open Authentication (OAuth 2.0) for user accounts

projects.title: Uno Port Art Films
projects.subtitle: a site for a summer outdoor film festival in Japan
projects.description: Built on WordPress for future upkeep, I configured this new site on a short timeline to fit the needs of the festival. The key technical aspect of this new site was a new taxonomy system for organizing exisiting data and data types specific to the film festival.

children.text: This site transformed from a data dump of all of the past films shown to a navigateable site with descriptions, summaries, and help text.
Compare the following, the old Uno Port Art Films homepage, to the new home page pictured above.
portfolio/unoportartfilms/old-home-scroll.gif
Overall, the new site is cleaner, more streamlined, and guided.
From the ticket purchase page to the archives --
portfolio/unoportartfilms/new-buy.png
everything was put together with the experience in mind, to make all of that great content actually accessible and managable.

The archives in particular were set up so that users could not only navigate easily to find what they were looking for but browse new films as well. In turn, the taxonomy system was built explicitly for non-technical site administrators, so that moving the films from the current year to the archives would take three clicks: one to move all tags under the current year, 2016 for example, to 'Archives', one to change the menu link to reflect the new year, and one to save all of this configuration.

projects.title: This site, 2.0
projects.subtitle: a React site, built with curiosity
projects.description: After finishing my time at R/GA where I learned and used React for the first time, I rebuilt this site so I could have experience building with React from the bottom up. As evidenced in the description, I think it serves as a good metric of how much my mindset toward content and code has changed even within just one year. Enjoy!

children.text: This new website is a culmination of my time at R/GA in more ways than one. In addition to the new technical aspects of the site, I set my new focus for the site to be curation, as we had practiced in pitches during the apprenticeship.

I created the old site just about a year before this one, in the summer of 2016. Where the old site had contained everything there was to know about me-- my hobbies, my extracurriculars in high school-- my time at R/GA showed me that often, both visually and with regard to content, less is more.

The resume page in particular is a case in point. The old version of this site had a graphical CV that rendered all of my experiences as visual blocks programmatically to a canvas. However, what I didn't realize was how overwhelming the entirety of this information would be, as visible in the screencap below, for someone who had never even met me.
Timeline 1.0

Each of the blocks was interactive and represented an experience that I was involved in for that amount of time. But this randomly generated set of colors, as you can see here, wasn't appealing or didn't induce clicks in any way.
portfolio/muesugi/old-resume-timeline.png
Retaining the idea of the timeline and graphical representation that I liked, I thought about what experiences truly defined me in genuine ways. This, as can be seen in the
/resume
new resume page
, resulted in a more curated and meaningful graphical experience.
Timeline 2.0
portfolio/muesugi/new-timeline.png

projects.title: String / Strung
projects.subtitle: a Girls Who Code summer project for crocheters
projects.description: Created as my final project for the Girls Who Code program in the span of under a week, the 'String' web tool allows users to enter a written crochet pattern and see a visual approximation (using Raphael.js) of the intended product to catch mistakes before publishing patterns. The 2.0 site, Strung, is pictured here and is currently in progress.

children.text: As a crocheter myself, this project started because I found that written crochet patterns and code were quite similar. Not many people are involved in both worlds, though, so very few if any tools existed to help pattern designers and crocheters.

During my last week in the Girls Who Code program, my eigth official week learning to code, I made a rough prototype featuring a live editor, pictured below, that responsively generated graphical representations of basic written crochet patterns.
portfolio/string-strung/string.png

Recently, I decided to revisit the application-- now that I at least knew code style was a thing-- to create a more reliable, accurate, and stable tool. While the new version is still a work progress, it consists of three parts:
Chartify: for converting text patterns to 2D pattern charts
Visualize: for rendering 3D crochet visualizations from text patterns (using THREE.js)
Textify: a Drag and Drop tool for generating text patterns
